summaryMarkdown.html: The CPIC Dosing Guideline for oxcarbazepine recommends an alternative drug for oxcarbazepine-naive patients carrying at least one copy of HLA-B*15:02 due to the association of this allele with an increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

textMarkdown.html:
This annotation is based on the CPIC® guideline for oxcarbazepine and HLA-B.

December 2017

Accepted article preview online January 2018; Advance online publication February 2018.

  • The 2017 update of CPIC guidelines regarding the use of pharmacogenomic tests in dosing of carbamazepine expanded to include information on pharmacogenomic tests in dosing of oxcarbazepine. The updated guidelines were published in Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics by the Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC). Literature up to June 2016 was reviewed, recommendations and supplemental information were updated.
  • Excerpts from the 2017 dosing guideline update:
    • "There is evidence linking HLA-B*15:02 genotype with the risk of carbamazepine- and oxcarbazepine-induced SJS/TEN."
    • "Data describing the relationship between HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 genotype and carbamazepine- or oxcarbazepine-induced cutaneous adverse reactions in pediatric patients are scarce. In the absence of data suggesting a different relationship between these HLA alleles and drug-induced hypersensitivity in pediatric patients, the recommendations may be used to guide use of carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine in both adult and pediatric patients."

Table 1: Oxcarbazepine therapy recommendations based on HLA-B genotype

Adapted from Tables 1 and 3 of the 2017 guideline update.

Likely phenotype Genotypes Examples of Diplotypes Phenotypic Implications Therapeutic Recommendations Classification of Recommendation a Considerations for other aromatic anticonvulsants
Homozygous for alleles other than HLA-B*15:02 Non-carrier of HLA-B*15:02. No HLA-B*15:02 alleles reported, often reported as "negative" on genotyping tests. *X/*X b Normal or reduced risk of oxcarbazepine-induced SJS/TEN. Use oxcarbazepine per standard dosing guidelines. Strong
Heterozygote or homozygous for HLA-B*15:02 Carrier of HLA-B*15:02. One or two *15:02 alleles, often reported as "positive" on a genotyping test. *15:02/*X b
*15:02/*15:02		 Increased risk of oxcarbazepine-induced SJS/TEN A. If patient is oxcarbazepine-naive, do not use oxcarbazepine.
B. The latency period for drug-induced SJS/TEN is short with continuous dosing and adherence to therapy (~4-28 days), and cases usually occur within 3 months of dosing; therefore, if the patient has previously used oxcarbazepine consistently for longer than 3 months without incidence of cutaneous adverse reactions, cautiously consider use of oxcarbazepine in the future.		 A. Strong
B. Optional		 A. Other aromatic anticonvulsants (e.g. eslicarbazepine, lamotrigine, phenytoin, fosphenytoin and phenoarbital) have weaker evidence linking SJS/TEN with the HLA-B*15:02 allele; however, caution should still be used in choosing an alternative agent.
B. Previous tolerance of oxcarbazepine is not indicative of tolerance to other aromatic anticonvulsants.

a Rating scheme described in the 2017 update supplement (see above)

b *X = any HLA-B genotype other than *15:02

HLA-B = human leukocyte antigen B
